commentBody:
Am I the only one who thinks the Warrior"s hubris ("We're better than the Showtime Lakers" - whether said in half jest or not) was at least in some way a part of their 2016 downfall? Pushing to get bragging rights for 73 wins, tauntingly saying LeBron's feelings were hurt, acting like it was over after the first two games of the championship series, bemoaning the officials - swagger is one thing, confidence another, but hubris - well, let's see if they continue to act like anointed champions before the first whistle of the season has even blown. If they do, it wouldn't surprise me to see them fall again, even with a great player like KD on the floor.

And Durant, great as he is, has never beaten LeBron nor risen to the ultimate challenge when it mattered most, and the Warriors' ring came against an injury depleted opponent. Maybe Curry was hurt in the finals, but he wasn't even the best player on his own team, let alone the league, in June. If LeBron had wilted like that in the finals we'd never hear the end of it.

replies.commentBody:
LBJ is on your team and you talk about hubris?!

Name one other person in ANY sport EVER who constantly feels the need to state, "I am the best player on the planet." Clock is ticking...

Go ahead, put your shirt on while you think about it.

The comments from Cleveland? Whistling through the graveyard. You got your tainted "championship". Now you join the '72 Soviet Union Olympic team in well deserved obscurity. Yesterday's news. Yawn.
Like what you said. Dubs need a James Worthy before they are "Showtime" worthy.  Or certainly some bigger defenders are needed

Without Kyrie Irving (who was huge). Without Kevin Love (who didn't score, but did have a positive impact, despite the naysayers).

No, the Warriors beat a gimpy on-man show. They definitely have something to prove to people. They need to erase that asterisk.
